content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really interesting to implement some algebra. The test cases are thorough and nicely paced. The expression rewriting rules are very clear.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i really like how you have implemented the algebra here

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving, see below.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Is it just this one or do all of the good contributions die in a committee instead of just being approved? :|
I like this puzzle!! Nice Job!
nice one
I think this is pretty good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really interesting to implement some algebra. The test cases are thorough and nicely paced. The expression rewriting rules are very clear.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving, see earlier comment.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Excellent contribution.
I still need time to solve the most difficult part (rewriting and ordering the subexpressions), but even now I can say that it is a very good exercise where you must be very organized to put together the different parts.
Also, the statement is very detailed, that helps a lot.
I'm still lvl 15 so I can't approve it, but hope you get the votes soon.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This contribution brought me back to primary school mathematics, and it thoroughly tested my string manipulation skills. The contribution is extensive and the case build-up is nice; I regularly had to change my code along with the cases.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I solved 24: The Long Game by brute-force and then elimination of those results not following the rules, so I didn't implement any parsing there. Guess I can't avoid writing a parser to solve this, lol.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "x=expression" to "{{x=}}[[expression]], and then format "expression" as a [[variable]] in the subsequent sentence.

Output section
* Suggest to format "x=" as a {{constant}}.

Constraints section
* Please mention that [[equation]] is always a valid equation and contains only one {{x}}, one {{=}}, and the characters {{0}} to {{9}}, {{+}}, {{-}}, {{*}}, {{/}}, {{(}} and {{)}}.
(I initially thought about mentioning that the equation contains integers only and no floats. But I guess the above description is sufficient.)

Cases
* In all the equations, neither the left hand side nor the right hand side starts with the negative sign. Would it be a good idea to add cases like the ones below?
-4+x=7
4+x=-7
-(4+x)=7
4+x=-(9*22)
-x=-6+9/10
-x-8*7=6*(-(22/7/3+9))

Thanks.

>> brute-force and then elimination of those results not following the rules

I really need to get better at considering brute-force for puzzles. Great idea!

I have made all your suggested changes except the last one about starting an expression with a minus sign. I need to think that one through and play around with it a bit as it would be a more significant change.

Thank you for the feedback!
Putting this puzzle together took significant attention to detail and I can't tell you how much I appreciate the time you put in doublechecking everything I did. Thank you!
I see you are 266th in Clash of Code! You might be level 20 a lot sooner than you think. Keep up the good work and thank you for taking a look!
Thank you! I have long admired your work, so your approval means a lot to me.
I do too!!!

"The boundaries which divide Life from Death are at best shadowy and vague. Who shall say where the one ends, and where the other begins?"

- Edgar Allan Poe
Thank you. It's amazing how much algebra we "just know" and don't even think about until we have to distinguish every step in an algorithm!

@arekbulski
It usually takes more time for harder puzzles to be approved. We wouldn't want approvers to blindly approve without vigorous checking either.
If you're up for a re-approval, this puzzle will go live. I'd love to have your name on the official approvers list!
Congrats on Level 20!
Thank you! In the next few days I will try to finish the exercise to give it a vote of approval :)
Are you familiar with the forum? I sent you a PM a few days ago.
Sorry, I didn't realize, but I already responded

Regarding having expressions that start with a negative sign, I like the idea and it was not terribly difficult to add to my solution. I will now have to add it to my test case generator and test it with more complex equations. I'm thinking about adding the following constraint:

"All terms of each equation are unique non-zero integers."

Having a negative sign in the front of an expression implies a leading zero. I'd prefer not to allow an explicit zero term anywhere in any equation. The only test case that is then not covered is the following:

x+3=0

Zero is a very unique number that probably adds unwanted complexity to an already difficult puzzle.

Here is the counterargument. For you last equation:

-x-8*7=6*(-(22/7/3+9))

What's the proper answer?

1)  x=-7*8-6*(-(9+22/3/7))    or 
2)  x=-7*8+6*(9+22/3/7)      or
3)  x=-7*8-6*(-9-22/3/7)

I'm worried that allowing negative signs at the front of expressions will require several additional rules and examples.

#3 looks correct to me.

0: I agree that a constraint should be added stating that there is no explicit zero term anywhere in an [[equation]].

Negative signs at the front of expressions: Such cases appear when some of your existing input equations are rearranged or rewritten. For example,

"Easy" test:
(49/(62*43))*x=168-(175*139+61)
may become:
(49/(62*43))*x-168=-(175*139+61)

or "Medium" test:
87*(20+(x+103-34)-100)=(122+126)-156
may become
87*(-(100-20-(x+103-34)))=(122+126)-156

Does your worry also hold for such cases?

Yes. Negative signs can create both implied 0s and implied (-1)s and I think both would need to be addressed in the rules. I have added 2 constraints that I believe limit all possible input to only equations that fit the rules of 24: The Long Game.

I was reviewing my notes and I don't think I ever addressed this concern of yours:

***
Negative signs at the front of expressions: Such cases appear when some of your existing input equations are rearranged or rewritten. For example,

"Easy" test:
(49/(62*43))*x=168-(175*139+61)
may become:
(49/(62*43))*x-168=-(175*139+61)

or "Medium" test:
87*(20+(x+103-34)-100)=(122+126)-156
may become
87*(-(100-20-(x+103-34)))=(122+126)-156
***

With my new constraints it is not possible for any answer to have an expression or subexpression that starts with a negative sign. You could have a negative sign in one of your intermediate steps, but that is your choice.

I believe I can write a detailed proof if necessary, but for now, let me just address your two examples:

Easy: You're welcome to move the 168 from the right side to the left side, but that is just an intermediate step and it will have to moved back to the right side for the final answer which creates a leading positive number on the right side.

Medium: Again, as an intermediate step, you are welcome to factor a -1 out of the expression (20+(x+103-34)-100). However, to get to a final answer you'll have to undo that step since you created an extra set of parentheses by doing it and the rules require a minimum number of parentheses.

I feel very confident that an equation cannot be written that when solved for X will result in an expression or subexpression on the right side of the equal sign that must begin with a negative sign. Let me know if you can think of other possible examples.

My earlier point is about whether new **questions** may be set which start with/contain a negative sign at specific locations, not the **answers**. The point will be resolved if you change "[[expression]]" to "expression" and add "in the [[equation]]" in the last constraint, I think?
I agree. Changes made.
